questions.text: Number of ATPs consumed during formation of one peptide bond during protein synthesis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
EXPL: 
1 ATP is hydrolysed in the aminoacylation reaction:
                Amino Acid + tRNA + ATP → Aminoacyl-tRNA + AMP + PPi
1 GTP is hydrolysed in the aatRNA binding reaction catalysed by EF-Tu/EF1.
1 GTP is hydrolysed in the translocation reaction catalysed by EF-G/EF2
No NTP is consumed directly in the peptidyl transferase reaction — the energy for bond formation comes from the ‘activated’ aminoacyl-tRNA.

questions.text: Which of the following is inhibited by Sodium Fluoride:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


EXPL:Enolase is inhibited by sodium fluoride

questions.solution:

The second major class of phospholipids comprises sphingomyelin, a phospholipid that contains a sphingosine rather than a glycerol backbone

questions.text: Increase in pyruvate and lactate is seen in which of the following deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
EXPL:
Many alcoholics are thiamin deficient (both because of a poor diet and also because alcohol inhibits thiamin absorption), and may develop potentially fatal pyruvic and lactic acidosis.

questions.text: Adrenaline acts on which enzyme in glycogenolysis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
EXPL:
Glycogen phosphorylase requires pyridoxal phosphate as its coenzyme. The principal enzymes controlling glycogen metabolism— glycogen phosphorylase and glycogen synthase—are regulated in opposite directions by allosteric mechanisms and covalent modification by reversible phosphorylation and dephosphorylation of enzyme protein in response to hormone action Adrenaline in Liver.

choices.text: Embden-Meyerhof pathway and H.M.P shunt pathway

questions.text: The main pathways of metabolism in brain are:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
EXPL: 
The maintenance of an adequate blood concentration of glucose is essential for those tissues for which it is either the major fuel (the brain) or the only fuel (erythrocytes). In fasting and starvation, glucose must be provided for the brain and red blood cells; in the early fasting state, this is supplied from glycogen reserves. In order to spare glucose, muscle and other tissues do not take up glucose when insulin secretion is low; they utilize fatty acids (and later ketone bodies) as their preferred fuel.

questions.text: NAD + reduced by all of the following enzymes except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
EXPL:Succinyl  Dehydrogenase is an enzyme of TCA Cycle which converts FAD to FADH2.

questions.text: Which of the following types of hypertriglyceridemia is associated with an increase  in chylomicron and VLDL remnants?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
EXPL: Familial type III hyperlipoproteinemia (broad beta disease, remnant removal disease, familial dysbetalipoproteinemia)
Increase in chylomicron and VLDL remnants (β-VLDL). Causes hypercholesterolemia, xanthomas, and atherosclerosis.

questions.text: DNA polymerase I possess:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
EXPL:
DNA replication enzyme DNA polymerase I was discovered by Arthur Kornberg, This enzyme has multiple catalytic activities, a complex structure, and a requirement for the triphosphates of the four deoxyribonucleosides of adenine, guanine, cytosine, and thymine.

questions.text: Collagen is rich in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
EXPL: COLLAGEN IS repeating structure, represented as (Gly-X-Y)n, is an absolute requirement for the formation of the triple helix. Hydroxyproline and hydroxylysine occur principally in collagen.

questions.text: Ammonia is detoxified in liver to form:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
EXPL:Urea by urea cycle however the major carrier of ammonia in the blood is glutamine.

questions.text: In human and other primates, as well as in guinea pigs, this vitamin cannot be synthesized because of the absence of the enzyme L-gulonolactone oxidase; the vitamin is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
EXPL:
Vitamin C is a vitamin for human beings and other primates, the guinea pig, bats, passeriform birds, and most fishes and invertebrates; other animals synthesize it as an intermediate in the uronic acid pathway of glucose metabolism . In those species for which it is a vitamin, there is a block in the pathway as a result of the absence of gulonolactone oxidase.

choices.text: Increased mobilization of glycogen from liver

questions.text: All are the true regarding glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
EXPL: Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency  is seen in Von Gierkes disease is characterized by Fasting Hypoglycemia,  Hyperuricemia ,Lactic acidosis, Ketosis.

questions.text: A relatively free component of the electron transport respiratory chain is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
EXPL:Complex I transfers electron to NADH to coenzyme Q (Q) (also called ubiquinone),Q-cytochrome c oxidoreductase (Complex III), which passes the electrons on to cytochrome c; and cytochrome c oxidase (Complex IV), which completes the chain, passing the electrons to O2 and causing it to be reduced to H2O. The four complexes are embedded in the inner mitochondrial membrane, but Q and cytochrome c are mobile.

questions.text: Which of the following is rich source of cholesterol:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
EXPL: Cholesterol occurs in foods of animal origin such as egg yolk, meat, liver, and brain.

questions.text: In TCA cycle, citrate is converted into______________, after losing a molecule of H2O;
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
EXPL: Citrate is isomerized to isocitrate by the enzyme aconitase (aconitate hydratase); the reaction occurs in two steps: dehydration to cis-aconitate and rehydration to isocitrate.

questions.text: A mutation that converts an amino acid codon to a stop codon is a:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
EXPL: A nonsense codon may appear that would then result in the premature termination of translation and the production of only a fragment of the intended protein molecule. The probability is high that a prematurely terminated protein molecule or peptide fragment will not function .

questions.text: Glycogen storage disease include all the following except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

EXPL: Glycogen storage diseases are a group of inherited disorders characterized by deficient mobilization of glycogen or deposition of abnormal forms of glycogen, leading to liver damage and muscle weakness; some glycogen storage diseases result in early death.

  • Von Gierke disease
  • Pompe disease
  • Forbe or Cori disease
  • Andersen disease
  • McArdle syndrome
  • Hers disease
